PM11:05am

Re Xi changing China’s constitution. What will happen after China’s Xi has been in power for 15 years? The middle class will get angry at the rise of corruption from the mid-2020s.

Our work on political longevity shows that corruption is the most obvious consequence of excess political longevity. With no constraint on the executive, corruption tends to grow (see the ANC’s rule in SA, Russia, Turkey) … or at least, corruption scores fail to improve even if wealth rises, if leaders are in power too long. So all of Xi’s anti-corruption efforts now – which may anyway be a veil that is used to remove political opponents – are likely to be undermined by being in power for 15 years.

11:05 am
PM11:05am

What makes this so interesting for China is that this is likely to become a political issue – because China is inherently a country likely to democratise in the long-term. The middle class will resent the lack of political choice under Xi. As you know, there are no rich autocracies except for those that export so much energy that they don’t need to tax people. The only wealthy exception is the city state of Singapore, and 1) Polity IV does not define this as an autocracy (rather, a closed anocracy), and 2) this is hardly relevant to China, as China is not a city-state. The only other exception is Belarus – which is supported by Russia. As China’s middle class continues to expand, and assuming they pay taxes, Xi will become the focus of their growing discontent in the 2020s.

We do not find much impact on growth or foreign direct investment from excessive political longevity. We also do not see a problem for China over 2018-2025 from Xi being in power – but 10-15 years is the maximum period when countries tend to benefit from political stability.

PM11:05am

In terms of the timing of a shift towards democracy – the maximum risk for an autocracy is when per capita GDP in 2011 PPP dollars is in the $8-15k range. This is where eastern Europe was when the Berlin Wall fell. A shift to democracy is far less likely when a country is as poor as China was in 1989. The important point about this, is that when autocrats look back at their own history, they see only autocracy – they fail to account for rising wealth and the need for political systems to react to that. See our work on democratisation in the second pdf (the Revolutionary Nature of Growth).

The resolution of ROP should see investors start to look at the value of the group as opposed to obsessing about ROP. We believe Provident is worth about £3bn on a look through basis and consequently if ROP were to cost £0.5bn (we don't think it will cost anything like that) shareholders should double their money. A clear Buy if there is 100% upside in a worst case scenario.

Decreasing target price: We decrease our target price to 80p (from 125p) and retain our Underperform rating. Our FY19E-FY21E EPS estimates decrease by 16-24% following the company’s strategy announcement and guidance. Whilst we view management's plan for the Insurance division positively, we continue to take a negative view of the larger Roadside Assistance division and the significant debt burden the company has.■ Ongoing challenges at Roadside Assistance: Although some of the headwinds to personal membership growth are behind AA, we believe the division will continue to slowly lose members and experience ongoing margin challenges from the increased operational expenditure and ongoing price competition. We do not believe the Connected Car initiative, or efforts to grow the membership base with younger segments, will provide the necessary growth whilst consuming significant cash. Improvements to the operating systems and flexibility of the patrol force have been mooted before and we wait for evidence of success before factoring these into our numbers

PM11:35am

Growth potential in the Insurance division: We believe there are lots of 'low hanging fruits' for the Insurance division to benefit from (only 9% of members also have motor insurance and broadening of the underwriter footprint) and which can drive growth in the near term, especially when supported by additional investment.■ Catalysts and Risks: AA reports full year results on 17 April. Risks to the upside include: 1) early and tangible success from the Connected Car trials and 2) paid membership numbers reverse the decline. Risks to the downside include: 1) further dividend cut to provide funds for turnaround programme and 2) further volatile work load patterns suppressing margins.■ Valuation: Our DCF-derived target price decreases to 80p reflecting our lower earnings estimates and risks to membership levels. On our estimates, AA trades at 10.2x CY2018E EV/EBITDA with 2.6% dividend yield.

BE11:36am

When the AA went public in 2014, its investment case focused on reversing declines in paid personal members, reducing back-office costs and gradually deleveraging the business. The company’s profit warning on 21 February has shown this plan has failed. Since the IPO, paid personal members have fallen by 8%, margins will contract 730bp to 36.5% this year, and leverage will increase to 7.7x net debt/EBITDA. With the company’s new management team planning to increase the level of capex and opex investment to drive growth, the planned deleveraging of the business looks more uncertain and further away. With less attraction for income investors following the dividend cut and a long road to recovery ahead, the risk/reward trade-off remains negatively skewed, in our view. We reiterate our Sell recommendation, and cut price target to 65p.

... and back to Berenberg for the important point on the balance sheet, that we've made many times here. In short, they're boxed in.

Bluesky21 @alewis2005 - there is a list of supposedly good “value” investors who lose their shirts when the tide goes out
11:38 am
BE11:38am

Downgrades to EBITDA guidance alongside further investment into the business mean that the AA will have a leverage of 7.7x net debt/EBITDA on 2019E numbers, or 8.8x including its £395m pension deficit. The immediate questions following the company’s profit warning centred around a possible covenants breach, and the prospect of a dilutive rights issue to de-risk the balance sheet. We consider both options to be unlikely – the whole business securitisation (WBS) debt structure was designed in such a way that the AA is more likely to continually refinance rather than significantly pay down its debts. Punitive early repayment costs (c£550m) mean that a rights issue would be uneconomical. As a result, there is no quick fix for the AA’s substantial leverage, which we expect to remain a concern for several more years.

Sugar commentary remains soft but unchanged versus the Q1 stage. FY 18 guidance for “progress” in group adjusted operating profit and EPS is unchanged, with H1 operating profit expected to be flat and H2 expected to show growth (phasing is in-line with our expectations). With the stock -13% in the last 3-months we think this in-line update is reassuring and that we could see the shares open higher this morning.

BE11:52am

It is less than 6 weeks since ABF issued its Christmas/Q1 update (covering the first 16 weeks of its 24 week FYH1), so today's pre-close update was always likely to be routine and so it has proved.
- The divisional commentary on Retail is likely to be the key focus for investors today given that Primark accounts for more than half of the group's operating profit. On a constant currency basis FYH1 sales were up 7%, (in line with the +7% reported previously for the first 16 weeks). The company has disclosed LFL performance (which it did not do in the FYQ1 statement): LfLs were -1% for Primark as a whole, though up 4% in the UK (implying, obviously, that LfL performance in Continental Europe remains weak). Encouragingly the statement guides to improved Primark margins in FY H2.

GBKrona @BE - why is Interserve getting whacked again today?

BE11:54am

Interserve is struggling to put ­together a crucial debt refinancing deal after the collapse of Carillion spooked its lenders.

The troubled British outsourcer, which cleans the London Underground and manages the Ministry of Defence’s UK estate, is racing to raise fresh funding from a syndicate of eight banks by the end of March.

However, some of Interserve’s main creditors suffered big losses when ­Carillion went under. Write-downs on lending to Carillion stand at about £1bn across the banking industry, dampening the appetite to provide financial support for the troubled outsourcing sector.
